name: 高等天文觀測
description:
Advanced Observational Astronomy is a (required) course designed for graduate students (in both Astronomy M.S. and Ph.D. programs) who wish to have astronomy as their career. The aim is to equip students with most commonly needed observational techniques and essential observational knowledge so they can understand modern day astronomical observations, and/or conduct their own observations necessary for thesis studies while in school and for independent researches in the future.

Because of the wide scope of the course and constrained by limited class hours, Advanced Observational Astronomy will spend most of its time on Spherical Astronomy (including spherical trigonometry, celestial sphere, coordinate systems and time), Photometry, Telescopes and Optics, and if time allows, on Optical Detectors and on Multi wavelength Observations. [Because of the unique nature of radio observation and its importance in Taiwan’s astronomy, observational theories, instruments and techniques in radio wavelength will be covered by another graduate course Radio Astronomy.]
goals: Equip students with essential knowledge, commonly needed techniques so they understand modern-day astronomical observations and may conduct their own.
syllabus:
**課程簡介:**

Advanced Observational Astronomy is a (required) course designed for graduate students (in both Astronomy M.S. and Ph.D. programs) who wish to have astronomy as their career. The aim is to equip students with most-commonly needed observational techniques and essential observational knowledge so they can understand modern-day astronomical observations, and/or conduct their own observations necessary for thesis studies while in school and for independent researches in the future.

        Because of the wide scope of the course and constrained by limited class hours, Advanced Observational Astronomy will spend most of its time on Spherical Astronomy (including spherical trigonometry, celestial sphere, coordinate systems and time), Photometry, Telescopes and Optics, and if time allows, on Optical Detectors and on Multi-wavelength Observations. \[Because of the unique nature of radio observation and its importance in Taiwan's astronomy, observational theories, instruments and techniques in radio wavelength will be covered by another graduate course Radio Astronomy.\]  
       Advanced Observational Astronomy is mainly for the 1st year graduate students. The course will be graded with two problem sets, one midterm examination and one final examination, contributing approximately 40% (20% x 2), 30% and 30%, respectively, to the final grade.

**課程目標:**

Equip students with essential knowledge & commonly needed techniques so they understand modern-day astronomical observations and may conduct their own.

  
Course Outline (detailed):

01.  Spherical Astronomy: Introduction

02.  Spherical Astronomy: Spherical Trigonometry

03.  Spherical Astronomy: Celestial Sphere

04.  Spherical Astronomy: Coordinate Systems (I)

05.  Spherical Astronomy: Coordinate Systems (II)

06.  Spherical Astronomy: Sidereal Time

07.  Spherical Astronomy: Mean Solar Time

08.  Midterm examination

09.  Photometry: Background

10.  Photometry: Filter Systems

11.  Photometry: Color Indices

12.  Photometry: Interstellar Reddening

13.  Telescopes: Angular Resolution

14.  Telescopes: Optics (I)

15.  Telescopes: Optics (II)

16.  Optical/Infred Detectors (I)

17.  Optical/Infred Detectors (II)

18.  Final examination

Course Outline (brief):

·      Celestial Sphere and Coordinate Systems

·      Time

·      Photometry

·      Telescopes and Optics (optional)

·      Optical Detectors (optional)  
·      Observing at Other Wavelengths (optional)
